task_description:
In the  experiment, each participant is given 36 different proposals to respond to. Each is designated by a trial number in the data set This gives 36 instances for the learnable parameters to be trained. There is also a pretask where the participant finds a number of tokens that correspond to their contribution to the group. This is designated by the variable "token_self". The other variable, "token_opp", is the number of tokens found the opponent's and represents the opoonents contribution to the shared pot that will be later divided by the opponent.

Note that in each trial there is a variable amount of money in the combined earning, so that two equal split_self variables do not represent the same "fairness".

Below is the description of each variable in the dataset, which will be followed by information about the data type of the variable:

trial_type = how much was the contribution [1 = equal, 2 = opponent more, 3 = participant more]
trial_role = the role of the participant [1 = responder, 2 = proposer]
token_opp = number of tokens found by the opponent
token_self = number of tokens found by the participant
combined_earning = amount of money earned in total (note that each token found is £3)
split_opp = the proposed share of the opponent (in £)
split_self = the proposed share for the participant (in £)
splitperc_opp = same but in %
split_perc_self = same but in %
accept = whether the participant responded accept (1) or reject (0)
accepted_amount = if accepted, what is the amount gain (in £)
accepted_perc = same as above but in %
proposed_perc = when participant is the proposer, what is the % proposed to the opponent

Dataset:

Dataset Structure:
Variables available:
- ID (int64)
- group (object)
- trial_number (int64)
- trial_type (int64)
- trial_role (int64)
- token_opp (int64)
- token_self (int64)
- combined_earning (int64)
- split_opp (float64)
- split_self (float64)
- splitperc_opp (int64)
- splitperc_self (int64)
- accept (float64)
- accepted_amount (float64)
- accepted_perc (float64)
- proposed_perc (float64)
- proposed_amount (float64)

Number of observations: 3276

delta.description: Baseline acceptance bias parameter (intercept) capturing inherent preference toward acceptance.

theta.description: Fairness sensitivity parameter scaling the disutility when the offer falls below the fair share.

model_specification: U_accept = delta + split_self - theta * max(((token_self/(token_self + token_opp)) * combined_earning - split_self), 0)

U_accept.description: Utility of accepting the offer for a responder. Negative values indicate a less attractive action.

delta.description: Baseline acceptance bias parameter (intercept) capturing inherent preference toward acceptance.

theta.description: Fairness sensitivity parameter scaling the disutility when the offer falls below the fair share.

token_self.description: Number of tokens earned by the participant, reflecting their contribution.

token_opp.description: Number of tokens earned by the opponent, reflecting their contribution.

combined_earning.description: Total monetary earnings available, calculated from tokens (each token being £3).

split_self.description: The monetary amount allocated to the participant as proposed in the trial (in £).

model_summary: A linear utility model for responder behavior, where the utility of accepting an offer is determined by the sum of an intercept (baseline acceptance tendency) and the offered amount, reduced by a penalty proportional to the shortfall relative to a fair share. The fair share is computed from participants’ token contributions relative to total tokens and the combined earnings. Two learnable parameters (delta and theta) calibrate the baseline and fairness sensitivity.
full_reasoning:
Step 1. Key Psychological Mechanisms:
• Responders compare the monetary share they are offered (split_self) to what they perceive as fair given their relative contributions. Here “fair” is defined by the ratio of their own tokens (token_self) to the total tokens (token_self + token_opp) multiplied by the combined_earning.
• If the offered share is less than this fair amount, a fairness‐sensitivity mechanism kicks in, reducing the utility.
• An intercept term captures any general predisposition in responders (for example, a baseline inclination to accept offers regardless of fairness).

Step 2. How These Mechanisms Interact:
• The offered amount increases utility directly.
• The disutility incurred when the offer is below the fair share is scaled by a fairness sensitivity parameter.
• The fair share is computed from token_self, token_opp, and combined_earning.
• Only responder behavior (accept actions) is modeled.

Step 3. Mathematical Form:
• Compute fair_share = (token_self/(token_self + token_opp))*combined_earning.
• The utility for accepting an offer (U_accept) is given as:
  U_accept = delta + split_self − theta × (fair_share − split_self) when the offer is less than fair_share,
  and U_accept = delta + split_self when the offer is equal or exceeds fair_share.
• This can be written compactly using the max() function.

Step 4. Required Parameters:
• delta (δ): a baseline or intercept parameter capturing an overall acceptance tendency.
• theta (θ): a fairness sensitivity parameter that scales the disutility when the offer is below the computed fair share.
• Both are learnable, with finite bounds, and no additional stochasticity parameters are included here.

Step 5. Mapping to Observables:
• split_self, token_self, token_opp, and combined_earning are provided in the dataset.
• The computed fair_share informs the difference between what is offered and what is perceived as fair.
• The resulting utility U_accept can be used alongside a temperature parameter (applied later) to compute choice probabilities.

The formal model specification is provided below.

<MODEL>
U_accept = delta + split_self - theta * max(((token_self/(token_self + token_opp)) * combined_earning - split_self), 0)
</MODEL>

<VARIABLES>

<SUMMARY>
A linear utility model for responder behavior, where the utility of accepting an offer is determined by the sum of an intercept (baseline acceptance tendency) and the offered amount, reduced by a penalty proportional to the shortfall relative to a fair share. The fair share is computed from participants’ token contributions relative to total tokens and the combined earnings. Two learnable parameters (delta and theta) calibrate the baseline and fairness sensitivity.
</SUMMARY>
simulation_code:
def simulate_model(trial_data, delta=0, theta=0):
    utility_values = []
    for trial in trial_data:
        token_self = trial.get("token_self", 0)
        token_opp = trial.get("token_opp", 0)
        combined_earning = trial.get("combined_earning", 0)
        split_self = trial.get("split_self", 0)

        if token_self + token_opp == 0: # Handle division by zero
            fair_share = 0
        else:
            fair_share = (token_self / (token_self + token_opp)) * combined_earning

        utility = delta + split_self - theta * max(fair_share - split_self, 0)
        utility_values.append(utility)
    return utility_values
